commentBody: Have you got a case of FOMO about chiming in on Puzzle of the Year? It’s not too late! You can still vote for your favorite this week in the final ballot. Anyone can vote, whether or not you voted in the first round. https://form.jotform.com/250186385916162 That’s where to go. ALL RISE! YOLO! (Okay maybe I’m getting carried away.)
An amusing and satisfying theme for this breezyTuesday puzzle.
I had a wry grin on my face when I finished this one.
Definitely feel like the Mondays and Tuesdays have gotten harder since Will came back. Solving them in what used to be my typical Wednesday times
Great fun! Plenty I didn’t know but the crosses revealed all. And a clever theme too.

What a lovely amuse-bouche! Finished in 6:38 (4:40 faster than Tuesday average), bringing my streak to 590 days. As soon as I saw the first theme clue highlighted, something made me click on the lower left corner for the revealer, and I guessed it immediately based on the length of the two words. That gave me quite a boost with the remaining theme entries. And now I want a Reuben 😜
Spoiler..  awol instead of AMOK at the bitter end

Trippy puzzle.  one neither SLOSHES through it nor solves on STEROIDS.  Perfect Tuesday.   

Thank you, Dan Margolis!  (What kept you?)

I must be in a funk. Every puzzle seems just a bit tougher for me this year. Over average nearly everyday, it seems.

I recall the same thing happened at the beginning of last year and I wonder if it’s my annual January diet? Brain needs carbs - or so they say.

It’s possible, I suppose - But I don’t think I would know TALESE even if I ate a reuben on RYE.
A little concerned about 5D is everybody ok? Seems like an extreme response.

Is it just me or are Tuesday puzzles harder these days? 

So many obscure clues (some of them, I know the words but not in the way they’re clued) and proper nouns for me, granted I could manage most with crosses. ISOLDE, NIP, BARD, DAR, DARKSHADOWS, DANDER, TALESE, OKIE, ROD. Too many for Tuesday imho

This one solved as a true themeless for me.  I got all the way through the theme answers, didn't see any pattern, and soved the bottom answers entirely through the crosses.  Finished the puzzle and didn't even see that 68A and 69A were the revealer.  And then, once completed, I forgot that I was going to try to figure out what the theme was post-solve.

Then I pulled up xwordinfo.com, as I always do before looking at the Wordplay column and comments.  And there I saw a note to "Read ALL RISE as ALL RYES.."  And at that point, it occurred to me that I hadn't seen the theme yet.

Question:  Isn't DARK RYE just pumpernickel?

Appreciated the wordplay in retrospect -- didn't see it while solving.

But as the great-grandchild of Swedish immigrants, I do have to point out that the puzzle omits the best one of all:  Swedish rye bread.  

My mother, an excellent baker, spent much of the 1960's and 1970's trying to match Great Aunt Alice's rye bread (and quietly suspecting that Alice had omitted something important from the recipe she provided).  Mom finally got there through considerable trial and error.  It's one more thing I really miss about her every Christmas.

Anyway, that's why I teared up just a little at the end of this crossword.  Miss you, Mom!

A general comment:  I developed the habit of copying any long comment I didn't want to lose onto the clipboard until I could verify that it posted, and many were the times when it was a good thing that I did.  Sometimes, the comments didn't go through, and I had to paste them back into a new comment box for them to post.  

Recently, though, I haven't noticed any problems with comments posted within a minute or two of being submitted.  This is a noticeable improvement for the tech crew, and should be noted.

This should go hand in hand with the puzzle going live every single day at 10 pm Eastern (or 6 on the weekends) on...the...dot....

That didn't always use to happen.  But it seems that that issue is also in the past.  (But it has been fixed for much longer than the first issue.)

Now if only we could get Wordplay to be available directly from the main Games page every single day, starting right away.  (There was an issue one day recently, maybe Friday.)

But I don't think the same kind of issue.  I think when this happens, it's because someone submits an URL with an error in it.

Overall, though, there's been an improvement in the user experience, technically speaking.  It should be noted.
Would have been nice if 43D were clued as "mononymous Korean singer"
ALII?

Lol respect for a theme that is a homophone of 4 specific varieties of a specific variety of bread. As a bona fide fan of a good Reuben (and having eaten them at maybe 5 different NYC delis), I approve.

Fun crossword. The theme didn't really add a ton to the solve, as others have mentioned. But I appreciated some of the clues. Nice misdirect at 53D x 65A. I had AWRY and had a heckuva time finding my error. Which is apropos considering the theme itself was A RYE. I'll see myself out.

There were too many trivia clues required to get the bottom-most theme clue without hints. It itself was a trivia clue, as I was unfamiliar with not only the show but of the type of rye bread. Otherwise a well done puzzle. For editors I hope there is some attention paid to these concentrations of trivia clues in one spot.

My mistake was that I once lived fairly near an area where pig SNOoT sandwiches were sold, but that was fairly quickly corrected at the very end. Finding that error distracted me from figuring out the theme, but thankfully Sam took care of that in the Wordplay column.

Thanks, Dan.
Trickiest Tuesday puzzle I've seen in the past year and enjoyed every minute of it.  More Tuesdays of this difficulty level please!
Dark Shadows! Thank you for recalling some delightfully scary afternoons.

If I'd been a mere second faster with this puzzle, I'd have beaten my best time for a Monday puzzle.

Still, it’s nice to have a new personal best.

"You lived at this bakery growing up?"
"Born and bread."

("Most days, I'd just loaf around.")

I solved this in Tuesday time without lookups, which is very strange considering I did not get the theme (even though the revealer was a gimme) and for this time in the week there were surprisingly many clues I did not know the answer to. The bottom where an unknown title crossed with unknown names and terms was especially nasty.

Can you imagine my horror when I saw the first themed entry and considered the possibility the theme would be sports-based? 🤣 In the end the theme turned out to be impenetrable for me, anyway.

So the theme was about rye bread? Poland has great bread, the best I've tasted anywhere in the world: high quality, tasty *and* cheap. Our sourdough is incredible - so good I sometimes slowly munch on a plain slice smiling like a madman. Alas, I know very little about American bread. I just remember being unimpressed by it in general on our American holidays in 2011 and 2013. Most of what we were served in the Western states we visited was strangeiy sweet, dense and either too dry or too wet, without any crust to speak of. Maybe when we finally visit New York we will be pleasantly surprised by its bread - a rye, possibly?

Strands Thread.  Please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button: 

Strands #331
“Stable supply”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵

Tricky spanner.

I managed without lookups (no great deal for a Monday) but I needed to make sure that a BOA had something to do with drag. I knew two meanings for BOA but I'm rather vague on "drag."

I did have to track down an error. I had filled in three of the crosses for 11D so the answer was obvious, but I waited for my next pass to fill the N in. And when I got to "Quick drink" I automatically inserted an S without noticing the harm that would do.
Shouldn't today's photo have illustrated last Friday's puzzle by Ernest Lim (Jan. 24, 9 Down)? What does it have to do with today's?
Looking for a little help (@Steve L, @Eric Hougland) with the Monday New Yorker puzzle, the 17D clue, why "chatty" ?
I found this puzzle delectable! I love rye bread in all its forms.
Oof. I personally hated this one. Had a hard time with the theme and the bottom right corner seemed impossible without lookups.

Perfect Tuesday, in my view. Nice variety of clues.  I didn’t get the theme at all until I read Sam’s column.  

I’m introducing my husband (finally!) to Seinfeld.  I honestly didn’t think he’d get the humor but he finds it as hilarious as I do. We just watched the Soup …. episode. Looking forward to viewing the MARBLE rye episode through his eyes. 

Remember the answer from last week FEDERALGRANTS? I was concerned that they were on the chopping block. Welp, today’s NYT says these grants as well as federal loans are suspended. I feel sorry for students, nonprofits and small businesses. I wonder if HARRIS would have done the same thing? 🤔  Of course not!

I’ll ABSTAIN from further comment. 

I hope you have a great day

I would like to say that I sincerely appreciate myself in handling the aggravation this puzzle gave me.  And all from no fault of my own, other than early on deciding that 67A just had to be amuLET,

So blameless was I.  Having never heard of an EYELET, it couldn't be the answer.   The first rule of crosswords is that there are no answers than I have not heard of.  About.  Of.

But I took this with good humor, with only minimal damage to the door frame that I took it out on.
After SEEDED and MARBLE I could see where this was going, but the revealer took me by surprise and made me laugh (groan) out loud.  Nice work, Dan.

4D “Item on a fire truck” 🚒 was my *hook* into this puzzle since I spent an hour Sunday carefully unscrewing a dozen tiny screws from the bottom of a Hess toy fire truck in order to unjam its car and loading ramp (because that’s what Grandma does — she fixes broken toys).

All ryes rise. 

That observation caused me to overthink the theme. 

But not all Jewish breads rise, making me overthink more

Rye, wheat a whitely bun puzzle!

Happy Tuesday all!

🥖 🍞 🥯
I thoroughly enjoyed the clueing to Barnabas Collin’s and “Dark Shadows”. It brought back childhood memories of racing home after school to watch that spooky, mysterious series. 🦇

I was mostly in sync with Dan's puzzle; all the makings of a PB!
Pleased at myself for getting 1A. right off the bat (except for a slight misspelling). 
66A. was my undoing and I fell into the trap of 19A. without checking 11D.

Typical Tuesday workout for me. Actually ended up almost exactly at my Tuesday average, but... must confess that even when I was done I was not really grasping the theme. Had to come here and read before I really understood it. No big deal. A couple of puzzle finds today. Here's one - quite appropriate for today. Probably did this one, but had completely forgotten it. A Monday from September 9, 2019 by Dan Schoenholz. A couple of clue/answer examples: "Very soft loaves of bread?" TENDERRYES "Neckwear with the letters A, B, C, D, etc.?" ALPHABETTIES And the other theme answers: STANDARDDYES SOCIALLIES Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/9/2019&g=17&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ....

TIL "zeugma" (thank you, @Sam!), and, from a dive into examples, my favorite, from Groucho Marx:

“Time flies like an arrow, fruit flies like a banana.”





Et tu, emu.

I feel now I have now graduated as a NYT crossword solver. 
OREO went in in a flash. Clues about T.S.A.? Nae bother. Got ESC, LSD, AWOL, EMU in a trice. 
I couldn't get the CBS clue (TV channel?) or DARK SHADOWS but you don't need 100% to pass.
I didn't know there were names for different rye breads, it's not really very popular where I am and choice is usually sliced or not-sliced. I'll have to go for the PhD next in order to figure out themes.

D7:  DANDER

It’s up.

A CSD ™ production.

I seem to have been right there on Dan's wavelength. I got the first themed answer strictly from the crosses, thinking "Oh, no, a sports-themed crossword." But as soon as I saw "SEEDED," I thought rye bread. Maybe because I've been living in a literal and figurative bread desert too long. Then the second theme answer solidified it, and made me immediately think of Seinfeld and the MARBLE rye episode. I almost missed the significance of the revealer, but had a good chuckle when I filled it in. A nice change from the recent more-difficult Tuesday puzzles. YMM have varied.

After “SEEDED” and “JEWISH” I was thinking “rye”, then that terrific revealer practically made me stand and applaud.  Just a wonderful theme experience.

RISE by itself could have worked as the revealer, but ALL RISE adds a terrific layer – nice move!

EASE is a fitting answer, IMO.  The NE and SW corners had to be given very easy clues because they are almost completely disconnected from the rest of the grid, and the whole puzzle, to me, felt traditionally Tuesday-easy, after several recent difficult-for-Tuesday puzzles.

As I scanned the grid, I liked the near-dupes AWE/AYE and EARN/EARL, and the cross of AYE and EYE.  Lovely answers in SNOUT and SLOSHES.

Sweet to see Dan back after four years.  His last puzzle, a Sunday (12/13/20) had a scintillating wordplay theme as well.

Thank you, Dan, for a great “Oho!” moment at uncovering the revealer, and for stimulating my taste buds by bringing a bread I love to the fore!

Did anyone else have trouble with today’s mini? I’ve been doing the NYT puzzle and mini puzzle for a long time and this is the first time ever that I’ve not been able to solve the mini without help. Usually takes a little longer on a Saturday but I always get there in the end. Just me?
My phone was at 55% charge when I started this puzzle, and at 54% when I finished it.
How does EASE solve CONVENIENCE?  I'm not familiar with that.
"Fowl Pole" reminded of feeding the chickens when I was country boy some 75 years ago. And has anyone ever counted the number of consecutive puzzle that didn't inclue "Oreo"?
Ha! super cute. I love an early-week themer where I can avoid the revealer until the end. It makes that final clue less revealer & more punchline—and this was a good one. Thanks, Mr. Margolis & eds.!

Our Monday puzzle is here at last!!!
I had AWRY before AWOL.  (Not every military installation is a "base."  How about 'post'?  And 'barracks'?  )

If COLE slaw can be in the crossword puzzle, why can't a COLE crop be a word in Spelling Bee???????

Anyone have a good source for dark RYE flour other than King Arthur Baking?  Their $hipping charges are exorbitant.  And their standard "rye flour" is actually a mix with a lot of AP flour in there.  The grocery stores don't have rye flour any more.

Great puzzle from Dan Margolis, but he has led us to expect no less!

Somewhat hampered by having AWry crossing BrA in the southwest corner, rather than AWOL and BOA. 
Good to see AWOL neatly clued, rather than confused with MIA, but I see the vexatious NCO has made a comeback.

Some proper nouns were unknown, and for a while I thought I  was staring down the barrel of a lookup, but I managed to dig up the necessary crosses. Last to fall was EIN, crossing the unknown person's unfamiliar name. Could have kicked myself for missing the obvious misdirection, there.

Good one.
This one just zipped along.  Perfect Tuesday puzzle. And I came in well below average. Kudos to the constructor!

Onion was notably absent, but the theme had me thinking of chopped liver (in a very good way) nonetheless.

Cute puzzle, but seemed more a Monday than yesterday's. Even AAH was properly clued for a Monday, unlike yesterday's "I see!". Suppose I should let that go already.

ALII/ALI was interesting. Recall being terrified by some episode of Dark Shadows, which I was mistakenly allowed to view when I was about four.

@Byron in Toronto

Responding to you a day late: "Words on a tinted bottle", for example. Still, I agree, the category seemed odd.

I finished the puzzle (relatively quickly), but still couldn't figure out the theme.  I had to ask my wife, who saw it quickly, before I opened up the Wordplay column.

This is especially embarrassing since I grew up loving Jewish, seeded rye, always purchased from the local bakery, never from the grocery store.  Writing this, I can hear the whir of the slicing machine behind the counter and smell the caraway seeds.

I completed the puzzle 4 min faster than my Tues average, but I don't consider it finished until get the theme. I spent quite a bit of time trying to parse the revealer in different ways, but I just couldn't make a connection with the theme answers. 

I finally gave up and looked at the column, where it was clearly explained in a forehead slapping kind of way.... of course! I'm familiar with rye bread, I just didn't realize it had so many varieties.  

I felt a little better when I read the comments and saw that more experienced solvers than I also felt the whoosh of the theme flying over their heads.
Should the "fill" in this puzzle be LOX and CREAM CHEESE?

I get "radius" and "radii." And I know crosswords needs some flexibility, poetic license.

But I just looked up "et alia" at Merriam Websters and Cambridge. I always understood it to mean "and others," and that is what they say it means

I plunked in "et alii" easily enough, but it nagged at me.

It seems it would have to mean "and multiple groups of others" or something like that. I am not sure what the plural of a plural would be exactly.

It may have been discussed elsewhere. I do remember seeing it for the first time a few months ago and there being a bit of  a stir in the comments. But I felt like bringing it up.

Haha, Dark Shadows. That takes me back. Never watched more than a few minutes. {I think it was considered a soap, and I was busy playing hide and seek or playing army.) But I remember it being a thing.
TIL you can jump right to a comment from the confirmation email. That would have saved me a LOT of scrolling. Haha oh well. Live and learn.

This puzzle was very simple, even for a Tuesday. If that sounds like  I'm bragging, I'm not. TAM, OREO, COLE , MAD, SODA, BARD etc--these are all stock and trade answers (or whatever crossword puzzle solvers call them). The upside, I guess, is I can strut around a bit today before my success wears off.

Lol at the thought of David or the Venus de Milo made out of marbles. 

Maybe somebody here will be more successful than I was at finding an appropriate image.


SEEDED meaning: 1. with the seeds removed: 2. containing seeds 

Cleave me alone.
14 proper nouns, not to mention DARKSHADOWS crosses with 5 others. the middle bottom is literally 5 proper nouns crossing each other. i think i can figure out where the puzzler gave up

It's funny how different people find different puzzles easy or hard. I came here expecting to see "difficult for a Tuesday comments, but instead I see "easy even for a Tuesday" and the like. I take solace in knowing I've come here and had the exact opposite experience. This one just wasn't my jam.

Zipped through the crossword with Tuesday ease. Absolutely no clue as to theme, even after uncovering the revealer. Felt quite relieved on reading Wordplay that TIL it’s species of bread that just don’t exist here (London possibly, but 99% of us don’t live in the capital).
 I’ve seen sliced rye bread in supermarkets, usually a German or Dutch brand, but that’s it. No idea it came in different flavours. Does each one actually taste different or is it a decorative topping thing? Would you eat specific breads with specific fillings? I find the differences in our cuisine fascinating.

ION  and with apologies for bringing RL into the comments. I’ve cancelled my subscription to the news part of NYT. Not a comment on the excellent journalism, but I can’t read about what’s emanating from DC anymore. I’ll stick to this lovely puzzle community and keep my head down.

Ahhh Dark Shadows. Used to race home from school (5th, 6th, 7th grades), grab my Tab and Light & Lively yogurt, and settle in!
Did anyone re-watch it on the Sci-Fi network back in the nineties? Soooo campy! So much fun with my own kids.

Always pleased to see a reference to “Dark Shadows” but it is ridiculous and deeply misguided to clue Barnabas as “creepy,” especially in reference to the original (i.e., the “old series”).  Barnabas, as played by Jonathan Frid, is guilt-ridden and morally complex; he is not creepy.  Those actual qualities are what made the show and character a sensation.  Not a great showing by the creator/editors on that clue.

I was born and bread for a puzzle like this. Loved the theme. The rest of it didn’t stump me much and I got the solve in about 12 minutes. I keep going back and forth about the clue for DERAIL needing to be “Force off track” since it’s usually a transitive verb. But I guess it can be intransitive too. It just felt slightly a rye.

I solved the puzzle and had to check the blog to figure out the theme! Did not connect the dots with "ryes" Thankfully I had just made a gothic / vampire themed gift for a friend, so I was familiar with Barnabas 🤣 otherwise the bottom right might have been tricky
Enjoyed this one, but like others here, I didn't grasp the theme until after I read the column. No worries though--I love reading the column and learning new things!
The area around 61 has far too many proper nouns.

This was lots of fun. A clever and simple theme, seemed like a perfect Tuesday level. Thanks, Dan Margolis. It’s good to see you back. And thank you, Sam, for your wit and whimsy. These days we need all the whimsy we can get.

As a big fan of bread, I’m disappointed that I didn’t get the theme until reading the column. I’ll chalk it up to being Australian and unfamiliar with the bakery culture of the US. Really enjoyed this one :)
OHhhhh—the first half of the four longest answers are sub-types of the type bread which is a homophone of the second half of the revealer! I don't know why that did not jump out at me immediately!!
I have to wonder how many solvers actually figured out the theme. I had to read Wordplay to get it, and I said, "hmmm".

This was fun but I'd forgotten ETALIA could also be ETALII so had to check that cos I couldn't figure out what an OKAE was (now I know it's OKIE as in a person from Oklahoma).

I'd also never heard of the author so the cross with SEEDEDTEAMS and SYST were lost on me. At least I know what CBS stands for now, I'd never thought about it before. Doh!

And not being a fan of rye breads, the revealer remained veiled until I checked the comments. 

Despite this, I still enjoyed the solve. Thanks, Dan!

This one seemed kneady, kvetched Tom.

Nice one Dan. worth the wait.
I enjoy all the different clues used to add Oreo into puzzles.
One of the few themes I haven’t gotten until reading the article.

This was a SERENE solve for me. Except for DARK SHADOWS which I got from the crosses, everything was up my alley with the fill. 
That includes Gay TALESE which popped into my head with just the TA, and I have no idea why. I've never read a book of his. It's possible I've read *about* him, maybe in Vanity Fair. 

As for the theme, it went over my head. Should I attribute it to being possibly the only Jewish person who dislikes rye bread (and pastrami)?
I'll stick with bagels (she says as she savors her daily one, with lox and cream cheese...)

Despite this puzzle not making me at all hungry, I found it very enjoyable.
Thank you, Mr. Margolis, with apologies for missing out on the clever theme.

I can be very dense at times, but i got the theme fairly easily.

Not bragging, 'cause I've missed some things here that most of you got easily.

Nope, just weighing in in case the constructor is keeping track.
*cries in gluten free*

A MAD EMU had a NIP in the NUDE with EASE, admiring MARBLE STATUES. Harrumph! I think that's as far as I can take this with connected words at the moment. Fun puzzle that had a little extra crunch for me in a spot or two, but still better than average. Count me with those who did not see the theme until the column. Still really enjoyed it though it's highly unusual for me to not get a theme. I was just glad, after SEEDEDTEAMS, that it was a sports theme. :-) Liked the reference for OKIE. "The highway is alive tonight Where it's headed, everybody knows I'm sitting down here in the campfire light Waiting on the ghost of Tom Joad" https://youtube.com/watch?v=2Nbe2O-mJmc

Late puzzle find - I'll probably re-post this tomorrow. For no discernible reasons I was wondering about spoonerisms and came across a rather amazing puzzle: A Sunday from January 13, 1974 by Edward J. O'Brien with the title "Mixed doubles." The first theme clue and answer in that one: "Spooner, e.g." WORDBOTCHER And the across answers immediately before and after that: SKIPTHETALE TIPTHESCALE And some other pairs of theme answers: EIGHTOFSPADES SPATEOFAIDES WINNINGSPIEL SPINNINGWHEEL SNAPTHEWHIP WHAPTHESNIP SHUNSTHEROE RUNSTHESHOW SECONDFIGHTS FECUNDSIGHTS CUSTERBEATEN BUSTERKEATON Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/13/1974&g=25&d=A ....
Ah!   I got this theme easily and early.   (I feel some redemption after being beaten up by yesterday's puzzle)   Fun!   Thank you Mr Margolis.
Fun one, and I was glad I had a SEEDED rye from Zabar's in the kitchen to snack on when I finished.

Groan.

(In a good way)

Can someone help with how 15A  "old fashioned prelude to a duel" solves to SLAP?   Is this a reference to a childhood card-game I can almost remember but not quite?   Like others I'm sure, I had "draw" at first and felt pretty certain of it...
27 down - Unless you’re on the Chinese Olympic team, in which case it will covered up and you’re still able to compete

Ahh... one more late puzzle. For no discernible reason an odd homophone popped into my head and I was surprised to see that it had been an answer in a puzzle - A Sunday from August 5, 2001 by Peter Gordon with the title: "HOMONAMES." The one that I was thinking of: GYMNEIGHBORS and some other theme answers CARRYFISSURE WRECKSREAD FILLSPECTER CURTRUSTLE DOCKHOLIDAY KNEELSBORE CLAWEDREINS Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/5/2001&g=113&d=A I'm done. ....
I have finally found the cruciverbal equivalent of a dad joke. Seal of approval!

ALL RISE made me laugh out loud when its homophonic twist was revealed. i LOVE rye bread--it's my go to bread for jewish deli sandwiches and my favorite for buttered toast at home. i am not a fan of the get-stuck-in-your-teeth seeds, even though they have a lovely flavor.

Minor nit, but SATAY is more Malaysian than Indonesian. 

Source: I lived in both countries for 3 years each. Tons of satay in Malaysia but uncommon in Indonesia.

This felt more like a Wednesday puzzle to me. Too many obscure clues and while I did appreciate the theme is was just way too niche, unless you’re into rye bread…

I’ve been disappointed with the quality of puzzles lately. Hopefully things pick up again soon
This was a Wednesday puzzle, not a Tuesday.

Even though people have — for years — been complaining  and asking that the derogatory term for those of Japanese descent be retired from the puzzle Will Shortz and the rest of the editorial board at NYT refuse to listen.  We never see “English slang for cigarette” used as a clue.  I guess we know his priorities.  If someone asked you nicely to not use a word that brings back painful triggers for thousands of people, why can you just honor that? It’s called being a decent person.

I usually get to the day's puzzles when the rest of the family is settled in bed. I generally enjoy the brain work, and can usually tease out the answers to contextually local clues, but tonight's theme had me scratching my head. Living in the great PNW, this area is almost as different from New York as basic white bread is from dark rye bread. Our main town is getting more diverse in restaurant varieties, but they tend to open and close before I can get there. Our food truck business is booming though with great food variety offered. Now it's past midnight and I'm hungry!

I liked the puzzle and I thought the theme was clever. It’s just a newspaper celebrating its hometown culture, after all. My mom has lately been on a quest for mild, unSEEDED rye bread - how our tastes change in different phases of our lives. ALII was a new one for me. Thank you to the constructor.
Although some found this Tuesday SOSO, it was a SERENE solve for me! Enjoyed the theme, did not get DERAILed. Thank you Mr Margolis!

I was a little fussy about photo OPS, because I think making it plural is a stretch. I was also fussy about DERAIL because I think of it as transitive but I looked it up and it can indeed also be intransitive so thank you for teaching me something new! 

And then I solved it and saw the theme and the pun and I ceased to be fussy at all. Thank you for a fun puzzle! :)

@Steven M. Just for fun I went back and did the very first Crossword in the archive, which is also the first one Will ever edited. It was a Monday puzzle from 1993 and it took me 3x as long as a Monday nowadays. So it could be a lot worse.
@Jamie I've done that puzzle too and struggled because of the amount of cultural references that would have gimmes to people in that time and are lost to the contemporary eye

@Jamie
Sorry, hate  be that person, but the first puzzle Will edited was the one for Sunday, November 21, 1993, which is a terrific puzzle.
Also, Will Shortz didn't establish the "Monday is easiest" pattern in the first week -- or first year -- of his editorship.

@dutchiris
Thank you!  I knew there was something awry with my entries DADA and PLASHES!

@Striker 

I think it's Will Shortz being back personally! I think his puzzles are tougher than Joel's! In particular, Saturdays!

@carrielewis 

Think your cell phone, not Grandma.

@Intermediate level 

My experience says no.  I have a couple of Tuesdays in the past few months where my time was significantly longer than usual, a couple where it was significantly faster than usual, and the vast majority were around my average Tuesday time.  This as per xwstats.com.

So as they say, your mileage may vary.  None of the answers you cited seemed particularly difficult to me.  And I didn't think any of those were crosswordese, either.  

Hope the next one is easier for you!

@Intermediate level 

A question of wheelhouses, I'd say.

Opera, Shakespeare, Geography, and Psalm 23 clues are somewhat specialized areas but not particularly esoteric examples.

A certain maturity, (age), helped with DARKSHADOWS and TALESE.

@Intermediate level 

My Tuesday times have gotten faster each week this month. I found January 7 way hard for a Tuesday (nearly thrice today's time) and today was standard Tuesday time. Middle two weeks were roughly 1.5x today's time.

@Andrzej You might be disappointed by an American "Rye". As far as I can tell it has very little rye flour in it, or at least, a very light variety of rye - it just means, "not completely white bread".

@Andrzej 

There is very fine bread available in the US, but the bulk of the widely available commercial breads are pretty bland and very highly processed.  I am fortunate to live within walking distance of a very fine French bakery, which makes great baguettes and the best croissants I’ve tasted outside France.

@Marshall Walthew 

I'm sure there is, just as some Polish bread is truly awful: if I knew how to navigate US shops as I do Polish ones I probably would have fonder memories of your bread 🙂

@Andrzej 

There is great bread to be had in New York City (and a few other big cities in America) if you go to the right bakery (preferably one with Jewish origins).  But bread that one finds in American supermarkets is sad stuff, created to have a long shelf life...and very little flavor or texture.

As Sam points out in her column, many of these tasty breads (and bagels and bialys!) have their origin in the immigration of Jews from Eastern Europe.  Some of them probably left their recipes behind, so I assume there is sill excellent bread to be had in Poland.

I'm tempted to make some comment about the Jews of Poland, but I prefer to leave this comment more upbeat.
@Oikofuge  I grew up with a bread box and have owned on as an adult, so at least some Americans are familiar with them.

@Mean Old Lady I wasn't criticizing, I said it was delicious for sandwiches! Just that someone from Poland might be confused by the US definition of rye.

And as for London, foreign food IS British food. Good luck finding something else!

@John Carson I was going to ask you about that. Often it's the last thing I find. I tend to work from the corners in.

@Bob T. 

Yes, working the corners is the recommended way to approach this puzzle.  I look for consonants that don't fit together and need vowels to make up a word.  

I've stuck with Strands as my first in the morning puzzle to get the "little grey cells" talking to each other.  I've managed to reach an age where I want to hold off cognitive decline for as long as possible.  So, what I'll do is try to identify as many theme words as I can, with out entering them, in my head and try to "see" the entire board.  

First goal is to figure out the direction of the spanner.  Today was interesting because it did not fit the usual pattern.  

This is only how I use the game and I know others deliberately save the spanner for the last.

@Francis 

An AGLET is the plastic-encased tip which goes in to the holes in your shoe. 

An EYELET is one of those holes. 

AYELET is a common Hebrew girl’s name. 

Hope this helps you in the future!

(The name is pronounced in three syllables—eye-ELL-et.)

@Francis 

I find your claim of "having never heard of" very hard to credit!  You lace up your new tennies, running the shoelace through eyelets, or fancy lingerie might have narrow lace running through the eyelets in the camisole's fabric, or your hoodie might have a drawstring that runs through a channel with eyelets at each end....  it's just not an unusual thing.

@Mean Old Lady 
Try a natural goods/health store near you to find the dark rye flour. Some of them mill their own grains. Happy baking! 🍞

@Mean Old Lady 
My go-to source for flours for years has been Bob’s Red Mill. The dark rye I haven’t personally used, but it has thousands of excellent reviews on Amazon.It’s less than $4 for 20 ounces and seems to be pure rye.

@Mean Old Lady I recently discovered Azure Standard: https://azurestandard.com/ An excellent source of organic flours, grains and other food stuffs. Order as much (or as little) as you like for zero delivery fees. Their rye flour is 1/3 of what KA charges. The catch? They send out a truck to a local “drop”. You go to the drop, grab your goodies and are on your way. Dark rye flour sitting in my cupboard now alongside wheat berries for home flour milling.

@Oikofuge 

Although AWOL being equated with MIA in a military context is jarring to those whose initial thoughts go that way (and of course, that is the original and most literal context), once you examine how the two are used in casual conversation, you can see how they meet crossword level equivalence:

Thomas: Richard has missed the past few book club meetings, hasn't he?

Henry:  Yeah, since he started dating that floozy, he's been AWOL.
or:  Yeah, since he started dating that floozy, he's been MIA.

I know it bothers veterans, but I'm just talking about crossword legitimacy here.

@The X-Phile It is a stage name chosen to evoke the sexual aspect you referenced. She is a major influence on the current crop of unapologetically powerful black women artists like SZA, Cardi B, and Megan The Stallion. Her verse on the song Monster from Kanye West's 2010 masterpiece, My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy, is absolutely legendary. I always found it a little sad that she wasn't quite able to live up to it. But that's more of an indictment of the pop music industry and our expectations of women artists.

@Helen Wright First of all, this site shows that it’s more like 20-30% of the UK’s population who lives in London: https://reddit.com/r/MapPorn/s/FnoUVC5SHE Which of course is not to deny that if you don’t live near good rye bread, you would have difficulty with this puzzle’s theme. Rye bread is particularly well known in NYC because of the high Jewish population, for whom rye bread is the bread of choice for deli sandwiches like pastrami and corned beef. If you recall “When Harry Met Sally”, what Sally was having was on rye bread. And although Harry was Jewish, she wasn’t. She just knew that when you go into Katz’s Deli, you don’t get your sandwich on white bread. https://youtu.be/lNEX0fbGePg?si=Gx400qSMacr9Da-Q JEWISH rye, the kind available at Katz’s, is firmer than other kinds of rye bread available in the US. If it has caraway seeds in or on it, it’s a SEEDED rye. And a MARBLE rye is a swirl of regular rye bread and pumpernickel, a dark brown bread. DARK rye can be pumpernickel or a lighter brown bread. I’m sure that with a substantial Jewish population in London, you could find good rye bread next time you’re there. Bon appétit!
